Grouping W/ARCs by site/seed isn't a current feature of the 
W/ARC-writing code. It's occasionally been discussed; see:

  https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1055

An open issue, and one for which different operators might have 
different needs, is how to define where a certain URI goes when it is 
referenced from multiple seeds, or when the path-of-earliest-discovery 
associates it with one seed, when other heuristics (actual hostname, or 
hops-depth-from-seed) would more closely associate it with another 
seed/site.

One approach might be to name all W/ARCs by hostname, or by 'public 
suffix' (registered-domain-name-shared-by-many-subdomains), but this 
could lead to a lot of small 'runt' W/ARCs for domains that just 
contribute a few offsite referenced resources to other sites.

I'm sure we're someday get around to implementing something here but 
it's not imminent/scheduled, so other suggestions (or contributions of 
functionality) would be appreciated.

- Gordon @ IA

On 4/1/11 5:20 AM, heritrixquestions wrote:
> Hi,
>
> what is the best way to do this:
>
> * I want to crawl several hundreds of websites (for text mining purposes, but also the images etc. for display)
> * I want to keep the crawled data separate per site
> * I want it to be fast (obviously)
>
> I'm new to heritrix. I started using 1.14.4. and used most of the defaults, except for restricting it to stay on the sites that are the seeds.
>
> This works fine already, but with the default ARC output, all pages, images, etc. from all the seeds of one job are mixed together in the ARC files.
>
> If I use only one seed per job, I get the files the way I want them, but it is much, much slower, because obviously the crawling politeness causes many pauses when there is only one host.
>
> How can I improve this?
>
> Thank you,
> M.
